title.value: SUMMIT: Scaffolding Open Source Software Issue Discussion Through Summarization
title.justification: The title clearly states the name of the tool (SUMMIT) and its purpose, which is to scaffold discussions in open source software issue tracking systems through summarization.
title.quote: SUMMIT: Scaffolding Open Source Software Issue Discussion Through Summarization

extractions.description: The paper discusses the challenges faced by users of Issue Tracking Systems (ITS) in open source software development, specifically when dealing with lengthy and entangled discussions. It introduces SUMMIT, a tool designed to help users collaboratively create and use summaries to make sense of these discussions. The paper includes empirical investigations, design guidelines, and user studies to demonstrate the effectiveness of SUMMIT.

type.justification: The paper includes empirical investigations of current summarization practices in issue threads from OSS projects. It also conducts user studies to evaluate the proposed tool.
type.quote: Through an empirical investigation, we reveal a complex picture of how summarization is used by issue users in practice as a strategy to help develop and manage their discussions.

name.justification: The paper addresses issues related to user interaction with issue tracking systems in the context of open source software development.
name.quote: CCS Concepts: • Human-centered computing → Collaborative and social computing systems and tools.

name.justification: The paper focuses on improving issue tracking systems specifically used in open source software development.
name.quote: For Open Source Software (OSS) projects, issue discussions serve as a crucial collaboration mechanism for diverse stakeholders.

name.justification: The tool SUMMIT utilizes natural language processing techniques for summarization of issue threads.
name.quote: SUMMIT uses techniques that automatically detect information types and summarize texts to facilitate the generation of these summaries.

name.justification: The paper uses the BERTSumExt model as the backbone for its summarization tool.
name.quote: In particular, we adopt a summarization method called BERTSumExt as the backbone of our tool [18].

is_contributed.justification: The BERTSumExt model is adopted from existing research and is not a new contribution by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: In particular, we adopt a summarization method called BERTSumExt as the backbone of our tool [18].

is_executed.justification: The BERTSumExt model is executed as part of the tool's backend to generate summaries.
is_executed.quote: The sentences cleaned in this way are then fed to the BERTSumExt model [18] which produces an extractive summary.

is_compared.justification: The paper provides empirical evidence on the effectiveness of the summaries generated by BERTSumExt in comparison to non-summarized issue threads.
is_compared.quote: Through a user study with 16 participants, we evaluated SUMMIT from the perspectives of OSS end-users and contributors.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The BERTSumExt model is based on the paper titled 'Text Summarization with Pretrained Encoders.'
referenced_paper_title.quote: In particular, we adopt a summarization method called BERTSumExt as the backbone of our tool [18].

name.justification: The paper specifically mentions using long issue threads from the scikit-learn project for content analysis and evaluation.
name.quote: We selected three OSS projects as a multiple case study to perform content analysis [26] on a sample of long issue threads to characterize the summaries and their roles within the issue discussions.

name.justification: The paper mentions using long issue threads from the Jupyter Notebook project for content analysis and evaluation.
name.quote: From each selected project, we then sampled the ten longest issue threads. We focus our analysis on the longest issues because, again, participants from these threads are more likely to be overwhelmed by the discussion and, thus, more likely to adopt the summarization strategy in their comments.

name.justification: The paper mentions using long issue threads from the TensorFlow project for content analysis and evaluation.
name.quote: For our analysis, we focused on the longest issue discussion threads sampled from three open source projects: Tensorflow, a machine learning framework commonly used for deep learning applications, scikit-learn, a general machine learning library, and Jupyter Notebook, a web-based interactive development environment.
